title: At what point is it valid to leave when you are being harassed/trolled/etc. by teammates?
body:
I'm going to guess a big fat NEVER, but just to humor the thought, what kind of harassment from teammates would you need to be getting for Riot to say "yeah, you can bail out if you want"?

Probably the point where people are telling you to commit suicide, right? No point playing with teammates who want you to off yourself.

replies.body:
In normals: If people are hardcore raging at you in normals I wouldn't feel bad at all for leaving cuz you don't need to put up with that... crap.

In ranked: If you leave you are hurting yourself and IMO should be punished. I know everyone says this but MUTE EVERYONE. Finish the damn game and take a break if it's really effecting you.

In both cases leave busters will put a mark on your record but I have faith that people in the tribunal won't vote to punish you if you abandoned a team that was truly verbally abusing you for no reason.
Tribunal doesn't see leave buster cases

I would say never. For one thing, if you leave you can't report them at the end game lobby. Also, you can mute them to not get any of that, so you don't have to endure it for the rest of the game before you report them. In the end, if you leave, they win. You don't report them (yes the system might note them and they could get hit by Lyte's test system) and you could get punished by LeaverBuster and such.

Current system sucks, then.

I don't frequently leave. Just when I either have unavoidable chores (refusal could get me kicked out of the house since I'm over 20) or when my teammates are literally telling me they want to shoot me. Mute just doesn't do it. If they are that vicious to you, they'll know when you mute them and will troll you in other ways.

Fair enough, I agree the system isn't very good for stopping abuse in the game.

Personally this stuff doesn't bother me, what some stranger on the internet says to me or thinks of me means absolutely nothing to me. I just mute them and move on. I acknowledge that some people are a bit more sensitive to such things for whatever reason and I also acknowledge that some people get more aggravated by the post muting antics than others.

>when my teammates are literally telling me they want to shoot me. 

The idea is you mute people *before* it escalates to that level, I think.

Personally, I've had a lot more fun in games ever since I decided to have an itchy trigger finger on the mute button. I mute people at the first or second toxic or semi-toxic thing they say. Sometimes I mute them at game start if they gave off bad vibes in champ select.

I can generally tell what they're saying from what my teammates say, and I can always unmute them later if I think they're being constructive.
Riot says never, because of the mute button.  Doesn't really help when they can still find ways to troll you though :(

Actually, it's not even this bad, 

>The System really is lacking once it comes to verbal abuse

Why do you feel this way? I think I've seen a marked decline in verbal abusers since the chat restrictions system was implemented.

>marking leavers as the wrong party in all cases doesn´t really benefit anyone but the flamers in the first place from my perspective..

It benefits the other people in the game, who aren't flamers and aren't leavers.

It's *very* rare that you get 4 flamers and 1 leaver (unless it's a toxic 4-man premade). And more than likely, that flamer turns around and starts raging at someone else, maybe you.

You're also making it seem like there's only one wrong party. This isn't the case. **The flamer is the wrong party.** I believe that the leaver is a different party, who is also wrong.

>And muting someone doesn´t make the problem go away....it´s not making the flamer any nicer just because you don´t see his chat anymore,

It won't make him nicer, but it will make it so I don't have to deal with him, which, for me, pretty much makes the problem go away.

I'm playing this game to have fun. Playing with a flamer isn't fun. Playing with someone who doesn't talk can be fun.

>he won´t learn a thing

Not from muting him, he won't. You're right about that. **Muting is a temporary measure designed to make that game more enjoyable for you. *It is not a solution for toxicity.*** 

What *will* help him learn is when you report him after, and he gets chat restrictions or bans. There are actually two kinds of toxic players:

- Players who know they are toxic, and don't want to change.
  - These players just need to get banned. They don't belong in our community.


- Players who don't know they are toxic.
  - These players are usually swept up in the heat of the moment.
    - They're not going to listen to you, and they're not going to change their behavior *right then.* You need to let them know they're being toxic *when they calm down.*
  - When these players receive chat restrictions or bans, that's a wake-up call.
  - These players realize they're toxic, and work to stop
    - This is why 70% of players who receive chat bans stop being toxic.

- (There's kind of a 3rd, players who know they are toxic and want to change, but these tend to stop being toxic pretty quickly, so I'm not going to worry about them.)

>you still will feel abused and unwillling to play a game with that guy -snip-

I've found that when someone is raging at me, one of two things happens:

1. They say something toxic, or even borderline toxic, even if it's not directed at me, and **I mute them right away.**
  - I might get a little annoyed, but I forget about it pretty quickly and still have a fun game.
2. They say something toxic, and I don't mute them. **They keep being toxic for a long time before I finally mute them.**
  - Now, when I mute them, I am still thinking about how toxic they were, and it ruins the game for me.
 
> Being the bigger/better man doesn´t mean that you silently take the hits and carry on - it means that you stand up for yourself and others in need.

The problem is that if you take the analogy this far, it stops being able to translate into league, because in League, there is no option to report the player in-game.

Let's try to make the analogy a little closer. Remember, there are also 3 other people on the project with you, who are going to keep working on it whatever you do. The guy who slapped you is perfectly capable of working on the project with you, as long as you don't see each other in person (that is, he's capable of playing with you as long as he can't talk to you). After the slap, your options are:

- Slap him back (flame him back)
- Quit the project (afk)
- Keep working on the project and let him keep slapping you, then report him to your boss (keep playing without muting him, then report him)
- Go to a different room, where he can't hit you, finish the project, then report him to your boss (mute him, then report him at the end)

Amongst these options I think the last one is clearly the best. If there's another option that exists in league that I haven't included here, let me know, but I just fail to see what you could do that would be more correct, morally/ethically.

>The problem is that if you take the analogy this far, it stops being able to translate into league, because in League, there is no option to report the player in-game.

So...maybe that is the problem to begin with? If the system that checks for bad laguage would invoke ingame-votes (4/0) to throw the player asap and end the game if it detects toxic laguage, maybe that would be an improvment?

How is this any different than just surrendering so you don't have to deal with a toxic player?

  - If it requires 4 votes and 20 minutes and gives a loss, it isn't any different than just surrendering and reporting after.
  - If it doesn't give a loss, teams could use this to avoid getting losses on their record, when they know they're going to lose.
  - If it requires 3 votes, 3 players could abuse this to end games where two players don't want to surrender.
  - If it can be used before 20 minutes, players could use this instead of surrendering.

It might also encourage players who want to surrender (but their team doesn't want to) to be toxic.

OK. I guess this is where we differ in opinion a little bit.

I think we're in agreement here, that **muting is not a solution to the problem.** However, I contest that *muting is a way to make that game more enjoyable for you.* 

If you were in game with your friends, who you play with all the time, and one of your friends is toxic, I agree, muting them is a very bad solution. But in SoloQ, these are people who you'll probably never see again. You can't solve their toxicity in-game; you have to look at ways to tackle toxicity at a system-wide issue. You can, however, use the mute button to make a more enjoyable experience for yourself, in game. If you want to look at it from another perspective, use the mute button so that flamers won't get you mad, and turn you into a flamer. I'd encourage you to consider using it more.

I also think it's important to reduce toxicity in league, so the mute button isn't needed. I just think that initiatives like the Tribunal are the way to do this, not by individual players, one game at a time, because in-game, the flamers are worked-up, and not likely to listen or think clearly.

Any system that punishes a player mid-game for toxicity, also stops that game, though. So yes, it might be effective at combating toxicity, but at what cost?

I actually think your point is one of the reasons chat restrictions are awesome - because players interact with other players who have been chat restricted, they know the system is working.
